title: Traveling & MG

content: When I was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis (MG) three years ago, I wondered if traveling was still possible.
I love to travel, but the idea seemed far from reality as I sat in an ICU bed, barely walking, using a wheelchair.
Travelling while having difficulty walking and climbing stairs, difficulty swallowing, and trouble with my vision didn’t seem smart. Plus I still had chronic pain from surgery complications.

Forward to a year and a half later. I started feeling a little stable again. I made good friends in the MG community. I was starting to be physically active again, hitting the gym and doing physiotherapy. One day, one of my MG friends posted on her socials that she was traveling. I remember asking how she was able to travel with this condition.
She told me she was afraid to at first, but that she likes traveling, just like me. She gave me the confidence and push I needed, along with some tips.

content: I’ve now traveled three times since my MG diagnosis, with some ups and downs.

Summer 2024 was my best friend’s wedding back home. I decided to work towards that goal and get clearance from my doctors to travel. I did all the necessary tests and scans at the hospital to confirm I was still cancer free and my MG was stable. Once cleared, I booked my ticket with enough layover time to rest between flights.
In addition, I requested special assistance.
I knew nothing about it, and this is something I never thought I’d need. Especially not at my age. But having MG and travelling alone meant I needed to get over my shame and fear — and do it.
Special assistance can be given in different ways.
bullets: If you have a wheelchair, you can travel with it and ask for help from airport staff to wheel you through the airport.

If you don’t own a wheelchair and you have difficulty walking long distances and climbing stairs, you can request wheelchair assistance in all airports. A staff member from your airline or the airport will help wheel you in, get you through security, and get you to the gate.

If you don’t own a wheelchair and you have difficulty walking long distances and climbing stairs, you can request wheelchair assistance in all airports. A staff member from your airline or the airport will help wheel you in, get you through security, and get you to the gate.

content: You also get priority boarding since you have special assistance. I can’t tell you how much energy this has saved me.
bullets: Update your medical ID on your phone in case something happens. Have an emergency MG card in hand that you can show to the plane crew in case you need help, and to help explain your situation.
Plan your itinerary to have the most fun, keeping your condition in mind. Take time for naps, and take breaks from plans when you have to shower and such.
If you’re traveling alone, alert someone about your condition. It could be the hotel receptionist, for example.
Keep with you any documents from your doctor explaining your disease and what medications you take.
Take extra medications with you, just in case.
Purchase travel insurance, the best one you can. When going to a foreign country where you don’t know doctors and hospitals, be cautious and prepared in case of an emergency.

content: Finally, don’t be afraid to go. And have fun! Having MG doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy life anymore. It just means you need to make a few changes along the way.
When I travel now, my boyfriend loves to wheel me around, and we have the best time at the airport. Don’t be ashamed of this step. If it helps you, that’s all that matters.
